body: Lou Vairo, the Brooklyn-born coach of the United States national hockey team, has been impressed with the play of his goalie - Jim Craig, one of the heroes of the 1980 Olympic champions. Craig, whose status as a pro is not a factor in anything other than the Olympics, turned in a shutout earlier this week against a Dutch team. ''He's sensational. I
title: SCOUTING; Praise for Craig

body: The 23-year-old wife of a Brooklyn police officer was killed by a bullet from her husband's service revolver Sunday night as the couple were visiting friends in the Canarsie section. A preliminary investigation indicated that the shooting was accidental, the police reported. As the officer, George Cesiro, 26, was taking off the belt that held his
title: THE CITY; Officer's Gun Kills Wife in Brooklyn

body: A Brooklyn man surrendered to the police yesterday and was charged in three of 11 robberies committed early Friday by gunmen who kicked in the doors of homes and apartments in Queens and Brooklyn and accosted other victims in the streets. The suspect, 22-year-old Larry Jeffries of 275 Livonia Avenue in the East New York section, was also charged
title: SUSPECT SURRENDERS IN SPREE OF ROBBERIES AND BEATINGS

body: A task force of 30 detectives questioned witnesses, examined evidence and tracked leads yesterday in a widening hunt for three gunmen who staged 11 predawn robberies Friday, breaking into homes and accosting victims on streets in Queens and Brooklyn. At least two men were being questioned in the case. But the police filed no charges, did not
title: POLICE SEEK LEADS IN ROBBERY SPREE

body: In a three-hour spree of robbery, violence and death threats, three gunmen kicked in the doors of eight homes in Queens and Brooklyn, staged three street holdups and escaped in a pair of stolen cars early yesterday after eluding the police in two wild auto chases. The police said the robbers terrified householders with a shotgun and a handgun. They
title: 3 GUNMEN INVADE 8 HOMES AND BEAT AND ROB VICTIMS

body: A long stretch of the BMT Canarsie line in Brooklyn was shut down yesterday afternoon when gasoline spilled at a service station and seeped into the subway, officials said. Power was turned off in both directions on the line from the Myrtle Avenue-Wyckoff station in Brooklyn to First Avenue in Manhattan. The line runs from Canarsie to the West Side
title: THE CITY; Gasoline Spill Shuts Part of BMT Line

body: Three weeks after Election Day, a State Assembly election in Queens has produced a forgery investigation, charges of questionable campaign tactics and a protest meeting of civic activists. The controversy surrounds campaign mailings and literature of John F. Duane, a Democrat who defeated Assemblyman Douglas N. Prescott, a Republican, in the 25th
title: QUEENS ASSEMBLY RACE SPURS DISPUTE ON TACTICS

body: IONA traveled to the Great Alaska Shootout last November to further its plan of gaining a national reputation in college basketball. Victories over Ohio State and Washington State enhanced that effort and started the Gaels to a 24-9 season. Seven of those triumphs came in the Metro Atlantic Conference, which conducted formal play for the first time
title: LOCAL COLLEGE BASKETBALL: THE BATTLE FOR STATUS IS ON

body: James Madison High School of Brooklyn won its second Public Schools Athletic Association B Division title with a 36-8 victory over previously undefeated Far Rockaway. Madison, which lost two of its first three games this season, finished with seven straight victories. The Golden Knights, who last won the title in 1977, will play Maria Regina of the
title: JOHN ADAMS AND MADISON CAPTURE P.S.A.L. TITLES

body: Reasoning that New York City ''should not be in the business of running a cemetery,'' the city's Department of General Services said last June that it would sell Canarsie Cemetery in Brooklyn. The 13-acre cemetery, which is more than a hundred years old, fell into the city's hands after World War II. An audit was to determine its value, and the
title: FOLLOW-UP ON THE NEWS; Cemetery Sale

body: A police officer was accidentally shot in the left leg by his partner yesterday as the two chased four teen-agers suspected of stealing a car in Brooklyn, the police said. The wounded officer was identified as Timothy Barry of the 60th Precinct in the Coney Island section. He suffered a superficial leg wound when his partner, Joseph Revello,
title: Brooklyn Officer Slightly Hurt When Partner's Gun Goes Off

body: A 42-year-old off-duty police officer was fatally shot early yesterday on a Brooklyn street after he intervened in a dispute between a man and a woman, the police said. The officer, James Whittington, was shot three times a few minutes after midnight in front of 340 Dumont Avenue in the Brownsville section, said John Clifford, a spokesman for the
title: OFF-DUTY OFFICER SLAIN IN BROOKLYN

body: Bayside, the P.S.A.L. champions for the last three seasons, squeaked into this year's playoffs by scoring all of its points after intermission in a 34-0 victory over Beach Channel in a decisive Queens A division game. Richie Kaval, the Commodores' junior running back, broke the scoreless tie by scoring the first of his two touchdowns on a 4-yard
title: BAYSIDE WINS BY 34-0 TO GAIN PLAYOFF SPOT

body: Darnell Ethridge of John F. Kennedy High in the Bronx, is almost certain to become a 1,000-yard rusher before the end of the season, but while the DeWitt Clinton defense was keying on him yesterday, his teammate, Vernon Parker, was doing most of the damage as the Knights shut out the Governors, 28-0. The Governors held Ethridge to 42 yards rushing,
title: PARKER OF KENNEDY PLAYS THE KEY ROLE IN ROUT OF CLINTON

body: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Eunice Fried is a wine writer based in New York. By EUNICE FRIED UMBERTO DE MEO bought 60 crates of muscat and Thompson seedless grapes last Saturday and, for the 40th time in his 57 years, he will be making his own wine. In his youth Mr. De Meo made wine with his father in
title: HARVEST TIME FOR HOME WINE MAKERS

body: New York City officials hope to divert $88 million from the construction of a new sewage plant so they can repair two crumbling treatment plants in Brooklyn that now threaten to release raw sewage into surrounding waters. Last month the city said it was scaling down plans for the North River plant on Manhattan's Upper West Side, thereby saving $240
title: NEW YORK ACTS TO END THREAT OF SEWAGE SPILL

body: Jefferson's Orange Wave, led by the fullback Ricky Johnson and the tailback Anthony Simpson, racked up 298 yards of total offense, all of it on the ground, to trounce Lincoln, 30-0, on the loser's field. Johnson had 102 yards on 10 carries, including touchdown runs of 3 and 1 yards. Simpson did not score, but carried the ball 16 times for 90 yards.
title: JEFFERSON TROUNCES LINCOLN

body: A.D. BRONX CUOMO KOCH CURRAN LEHRMAN 73. Mott Haven, Hunts Point 6,210 6,203 65 101 74. Soundview, Bronx River 5,815 4,886 114 314 75. Parkchester, Throgs Neck, Castle Hill 7,071 5,270 406 1,334 76. Highbridge, Morris Heights 4,573 3,935 29 88 77. University Heights, Fordham 3,298 2,976 60 245 78. Morrisania, East Tremont 5,585 5,096 71 242 79.
title: CITY VOTE FOR TOP STATE OFFICES BY ASSEMBLY DISTRICTS; DEMOCRATIC REPUBLICAN GOVERNOR GOVERNOR

body: EARLY last week, a delegation of five tenants from a three-building c omplex on St. Johns Place in the Park Slope section of Brooklyn wenti nto a local office of the Department of Housing Preservation and D evelopment to meet their new landlord: New York City. Their 50-unit complex was seized on Aug. 13 by the city in the first phase of a
title: NEW LAW REDUCES BROOKLYN TAX FORECLOSURES

body: Six days a week, just after 6 A.M., the steel doors of the Sanitation Department's Brooklyn-South equipment garage, on an industrial stretch of Georgia Avenue, slide open for a fleet of 47 garbage collection trucks departing for the streets of the southeastern corner of the borough. The vehicles that lumber out of the ancient, lamp-lit garage bound
title: CITY SAYS NEW SANITATION TRUCKS PROVE WORTH

body: In June, New York City announced that it was putting Canarsie Cemetery in Brooklyn up for sale. The city had owned the 13-acre cemetery since World War II and had decided, in the words of Stuart Fischer, a spokesman for the Department of General Services, that ''the city should not be in the business of running a cemetery.'' There are 5,000 coffins
title: FOLLOW-UP ON THE NEWS; Cemetery for Sale

body: Were the Dodgers returning to Brooklyn? Not likely. But State Senator Thomas J. Bartosiewicz of Brooklyn said he would like ''to bring major league baseball back to the borough that proved you can win by losing,'' and in February he got the State Legislature to approve $30,000 for a feasibility study of building a domed sports stadium for the
title: FOLLOW-UP ON THE NEWS; Brooklyn Stadium

body: The resignation of Frederick W. Richmond from the House of Representatives has left three minority-group candidates seeking the Democratic nomination for his seat in the newly drawn 11th Congressional District in Brooklyn. The district was approved by the Justice Department during the recent reapportionment process as a district where either a
title: 3 MINORITY CANDIDATES SEEK RICHMOND'S SEAT

body: The Last Checker Cab ''T he last Checker cab off the production line - please treat it kindly,'' entreats the sign in the new taxi Harold Winderbaum has been proudly driving around town for two weeks. He calls it ''The Last of the Mohicans'' and feels lucky to have it, despite its $11,000 price tag, plus loan interest - but minus air-conditioning.
title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY

body: New York will try an experiment to stop 18 billion gallons a year of untreated sewage overflow from entering city waterways. The project is expected to be in operation by next spring. The experiment involves a simple system developed in Sweden, and it would be the first time it was used in this country. ''If this works,'' said a spokesman for the
title: CITY WILL INSTALL SWEDISH SYSTEM TO TREAT SEWAGE

body: A woman suspected of using children to help her rob elderly people and enter homes was arrested yesterday after residents of the Canarsie section of Brooklyn followed her home after a break-in, the police said. The woman, Susan Forgas, 18 years old, of 936 East 95th Street, was charged with burglary and criminal mischief. ''A woman and kids knock
title: Woman Seized in Burglaries; Children Used by Her as Ploy

body: Air-conditioning units on New York City buses, both old and new, require such a high degree of maintenance that transit officials say they are fighting a losing battle to keep buses cool this summer. The problem is so extensive, according to one top bus official, that the city would be wise to forget about air-conditioning its buses altogether.
title: COOLING BUSES IS AN UPHILL FIGHT

body: New York City declared a water-pressure alert yesterday and Consolidated Edison said it had delivered a record amount of electrical power as the metropolitan area endured its fourth straight day of searing heat and high humdity. The temperature soared to a high of 96 degrees at 2:35 P.M. But by 7 P.M., with storm activity in the region, it was down
title: HYDRANTS CLOSED AS HEAT PERSISTS

body: A lthough negotiating turbulent rapids in canoe, raft or kayak gets most of the attention on television and in print, one should not forget the pleasures offered by quiet waters. The canoe is the ideal craft for moving along a lake or river with a minimum of intrusion upon the natural scene. A canoe is a highly portable, versatile craft that is at
title: No Headline

body: The New York City Health Department yesterday released the list of public beaches approved for swimming for the 1982 summer season. Following is a listing of the approved beaches: Brooklyn: Coney Island from Manhattan Beach to West 37th Street. Bronx: Orchard Beach, all of City Island and the Long Island Sound area from Lucerne Street to Schley
title: CITY LISTS APPROVED BEACHES

body: George Tabone (7-0) limited Holy Cross to three hits yesterday in pitching South Shore High School, the public school champion, to a 5-0 victory over Holy Cross, the Catholic school champion, at John Adams Field in Ozone Park, Queens. South Shore from Canarsie, Brooklyn, finished with a 31-1 record. Holy Cross, in Flushing, Queens, wound up 23-10.
title: South Shore Wins City Title

body: Wayne Rosenthal pitched a two-hitter and Vin Martino a four-hitter in leading their teams to shutout victories in high school baseball championships at Yankee Stadium yesterday. Rosenthal led South Shore of Canarsie, Brooklyn, to an 8-0 victory over Cardozo of Bayside, Queens, for the Public Schools Athletic League championship in the second game
title: South Shore, Holy Cross Capture Baseball Titles

body: Rick Cave of the Shore Athletic Club, a 25-year-old who never broke 4 minutes 10 seconds in the mile as a collegian, today outkicked Matt Centrowitz to win the 1,500-meter run in 3 minutes 43.2 seconds in the Adidas-Princeton Invitational track meet at Palmer Stadium. Cave, a mathematics teacher at nearby West Windsor-Plainsboro High School,
title: Cave Wins 1,500 Run in 3:43.2

body: Democrats swept three Assembly elections for a net gain of one seat, while Republicans held on to two State Senate seats but by reduced margins in special elections yesterday across New York State. In Suffolk County's Ninth Assembly District, Patrick Halpin, a County Legislator and a Democrat, handily defeated William Canary, a Babylon Town
title: DEMOCRATS WIN 3 RACES IN LEGISLATIVE ELECTIONS

body: THIS is a tough year to look for an apartment or a house in New YorkC ity, but it is also a year of opportunity. The availability of r ental apartments remains low - the vacancy rate was 2.l3 percent at t he most recent count - and high mortgage rates are forcing up the c ost of cooperatives, condominiums and houses. But a b orough-byborough survey
title: A HOMESEEKER'S GUIDE TO THE CITY

body: The greeting card was delivered to the gym at about the same time that the Brooklyn College basketball players began their Wednesday afternoon practice. It wished the players well and talked of how their success in reaching tonight's Final Four of the Division III National Collegiate Athletic Association playoffs had ''united'' the school. ''When
title: A Final-Four Team Grown in Brooklyn

body: When their subway train pulled into the Brooklyn Bridge station one recent day, two women who had been told by a fellow passenger that the the IRT No. 6 local would stop at Fulton Street, their destination, remained aboard. The sign on their car - incorrect - said the last stop would be Bowling Green, two stops beyond Fulton. But the Brooklyn
title: SUBWAY SIGNS OFTEN SIDETRACK RIDERS

body: Reasoning that there is strength in numbers, the New York City Transit Authority recently began setting aside special areas on subway platforms where passengers could congregate late at night while waiting for trains. As conceived by transit officials, the ''off-hours waiting area'' would be a low-budget item that would require little more than
title: FOR OFF-HOURS, SUBWAY ZONES FOR SAFER WAIT

body: Brooklyn College stubbornly held on to a slim lead for most of the second half last night to defeat the College of Staten Island, 60-57, in the National Collegiate Athletic Association Division III East Regional final at Staten Island. The Kingsmen, who led at the half by 33-31, and who fell behind only once thereafter, will oppose Roanoke (Va.)
title: Brooklyn Sets Back Staten Island, 60-67

body: He was a small-time robber from the Lower East Side, but Kenny Spulka had little fear of the police. They were, he said, simply ''pests.'' As the 19-year-old mugger talked in the state prison in Coxsackie, N.Y., about his life and crimes, he described the criminal-justice system as though it were little more than an annoying inconvenience. From the
title: EFFORTS TO FIGHT YOUTH CRIME CALLED INEFFECTIVE IN NEW YORK; Juvenile Crime Fourth of six articles.

body: Wingate used a zone defense and forced Alexander Hamilton, the defending champion, to wait for good shots yesterday in the Brooklyn quarterfinal round of the Public Schools Athletic League basketball tournament. Hamilton, which scored 100 points or more nine times this season, including its playoff opener last Wednesday, won but only by 59-56 at
title: Hamilton Held to 59 In Victory

body: Walter Berry, a senior center, scored 25 points, and Ken Hutchinson, a junior forward, had 17 to lead Benjamin Franklin to a 67-60 victory over DeWitt Clinton in opening-round play of the Public Schools Athletic League boys' tournament yesterday. The game, played at Brandeis High in Manhattan, marked the end of a long-standing interborough rivalry.
title: Franklin Tops Clinton; Berry Scores 25 Points

body: Alexander Hamilton, which had gained the final berth of the Public Schools Athletic League playoffs with a third-place finish in the Brooklyn III division, began its title defense yesterday with a 100-73 victory over Thomas Jefferson at South Shore High School. It was the ninth time this season that Hamilton had scored more than 100 points. Andre
title: Hamilton Scores 100 In Playoffs

body: On a June afternoon in 1913, when an army of schoolboys dressed in white shirts and dark knickerbockers demonstrated their physical skills at a Central Park extravaganza, Theodore Roosevelt clapped youngsters on the back with cries of ''Bully!'' and congratulated the Public Schools Athletic League for ''making these boys good young Americans.''
title: CITY'S PUBLIC SCHOOL ATHLETICS ERODED BY YEARS OF CUTBACKS

body: From his executive suite in the Greenpoint section of Brooklyn, Vic Barouh can check the sales reports from his $150 million officeequipment empire, call his factories in Ireland and Puerto Rico, watch his Ko-Rec-Type trucks fill on the loading docks and recall the day he started his business in 1955 with $48,000. What he finds himself thinking
title: AN ANGRY BUSINESSMAN'S WAR ON CRIME

body: Sol David, who survived Nazi concentration camps in World War II only to be murdered in Brooklyn by a robber who killed him with a single bullet, was buried yesterday. With Mr. David's widow, Flora, sobbing uncontrollably as relatives sought to comfort her, Rabbi Paul Gruber told more than 50 mourners at the Flatbush funeral service that ''we
title: A DEATH CAMP SURVIVOR, SLAIN BY MUGGERS, BURIED

body: International Israel has reassured the United States that it will not make attacks in Lebanon unless there is a ''clear provocation'' from Palestinian or Syrian forces, according to Israeli and Reagan Administration sources. The pledge was made, they said, by Prime Minister Begin in a letter to President Reagan. (Page A1, Column 1.) Washington
title: News Summary; THURSDAY, JANUARY 21, 1982

body: A 17-year-old youth was charged yesterday with shooting a woman in the head and stealing her purse, which contained only 50 c ents. The woman, who is 31 and has an 8-year-old son, was in critical conditionat Kings Coun ty Hospital. The youth was identified by the police as Kenrick Austin of 670 Remsen Avenue, Brooklyn. He was picked up shortly
title: WOMAN SHOT AND ROBBED OF 50¦

body: A woman was shot in the head on a street in the Canarsie section of Brooklyn yesterday evening by an armed robber who escaped with all the money she had on her - $10. The police identified the victim as Adian Barnes, 31 years old, of Brooklyn. Her condition was listed as critical at Kings County Hospital where she was taken after the shooting. Sgt.
title: THE CITY; Woman Is Shot On Canarsie Street

body: Air-conditioning units on New York City buses, both old and new, require such a high degree of maintenance that transit officials say they are fighting a losing battle to keep buses cool this summer. The problem is so extensive, according to one top bus official, that the city would be wise to forget about air-conditioning its buses altogether.
title: COOLING BUSES IS AN UPHILL FIGHT

body: New York City declared a water-pressure alert yesterday and Consolidated Edison said it had delivered a record amount of electrical power as the metropolitan area endured its fourth straight day of searing heat and high humdity. The temperature soared to a high of 96 degrees at 2:35 P.M. But by 7 P.M., with storm activity in the region, it was down
title: HYDRANTS CLOSED AS HEAT PERSISTS

body: A lthough negotiating turbulent rapids in canoe, raft or kayak gets most of the attention on television and in print, one should not forget the pleasures offered by quiet waters. The canoe is the ideal craft for moving along a lake or river with a minimum of intrusion upon the natural scene. A canoe is a highly portable, versatile craft that is at
title: No Headline

body: The New York City Health Department yesterday released the list of public beaches approved for swimming for the 1982 summer season. Following is a listing of the approved beaches: Brooklyn: Coney Island from Manhattan Beach to West 37th Street. Bronx: Orchard Beach, all of City Island and the Long Island Sound area from Lucerne Street to Schley
title: CITY LISTS APPROVED BEACHES

body: George Tabone (7-0) limited Holy Cross to three hits yesterday in pitching South Shore High School, the public school champion, to a 5-0 victory over Holy Cross, the Catholic school champion, at John Adams Field in Ozone Park, Queens. South Shore from Canarsie, Brooklyn, finished with a 31-1 record. Holy Cross, in Flushing, Queens, wound up 23-10.
title: South Shore Wins City Title

body: Wayne Rosenthal pitched a two-hitter and Vin Martino a four-hitter in leading their teams to shutout victories in high school baseball championships at Yankee Stadium yesterday. Rosenthal led South Shore of Canarsie, Brooklyn, to an 8-0 victory over Cardozo of Bayside, Queens, for the Public Schools Athletic League championship in the second game
title: South Shore, Holy Cross Capture Baseball Titles

body: Rick Cave of the Shore Athletic Club, a 25-year-old who never broke 4 minutes 10 seconds in the mile as a collegian, today outkicked Matt Centrowitz to win the 1,500-meter run in 3 minutes 43.2 seconds in the Adidas-Princeton Invitational track meet at Palmer Stadium. Cave, a mathematics teacher at nearby West Windsor-Plainsboro High School,
title: Cave Wins 1,500 Run in 3:43.2

body: Democrats swept three Assembly elections for a net gain of one seat, while Republicans held on to two State Senate seats but by reduced margins in special elections yesterday across New York State. In Suffolk County's Ninth Assembly District, Patrick Halpin, a County Legislator and a Democrat, handily defeated William Canary, a Babylon Town
title: DEMOCRATS WIN 3 RACES IN LEGISLATIVE ELECTIONS

body: THIS is a tough year to look for an apartment or a house in New YorkC ity, but it is also a year of opportunity. The availability of r ental apartments remains low - the vacancy rate was 2.l3 percent at t he most recent count - and high mortgage rates are forcing up the c ost of cooperatives, condominiums and houses. But a b orough-byborough survey
title: A HOMESEEKER'S GUIDE TO THE CITY

body: The greeting card was delivered to the gym at about the same time that the Brooklyn College basketball players began their Wednesday afternoon practice. It wished the players well and talked of how their success in reaching tonight's Final Four of the Division III National Collegiate Athletic Association playoffs had ''united'' the school. ''When
title: A Final-Four Team Grown in Brooklyn

body: When their subway train pulled into the Brooklyn Bridge station one recent day, two women who had been told by a fellow passenger that the the IRT No. 6 local would stop at Fulton Street, their destination, remained aboard. The sign on their car - incorrect - said the last stop would be Bowling Green, two stops beyond Fulton. But the Brooklyn
title: SUBWAY SIGNS OFTEN SIDETRACK RIDERS

body: Reasoning that there is strength in numbers, the New York City Transit Authority recently began setting aside special areas on subway platforms where passengers could congregate late at night while waiting for trains. As conceived by transit officials, the ''off-hours waiting area'' would be a low-budget item that would require little more than
title: FOR OFF-HOURS, SUBWAY ZONES FOR SAFER WAIT

body: Brooklyn College stubbornly held on to a slim lead for most of the second half last night to defeat the College of Staten Island, 60-57, in the National Collegiate Athletic Association Division III East Regional final at Staten Island. The Kingsmen, who led at the half by 33-31, and who fell behind only once thereafter, will oppose Roanoke (Va.)
title: Brooklyn Sets Back Staten Island, 60-67

body: He was a small-time robber from the Lower East Side, but Kenny Spulka had little fear of the police. They were, he said, simply ''pests.'' As the 19-year-old mugger talked in the state prison in Coxsackie, N.Y., about his life and crimes, he described the criminal-justice system as though it were little more than an annoying inconvenience. From the
title: EFFORTS TO FIGHT YOUTH CRIME CALLED INEFFECTIVE IN NEW YORK; Juvenile Crime Fourth of six articles.

body: Wingate used a zone defense and forced Alexander Hamilton, the defending champion, to wait for good shots yesterday in the Brooklyn quarterfinal round of the Public Schools Athletic League basketball tournament. Hamilton, which scored 100 points or more nine times this season, including its playoff opener last Wednesday, won but only by 59-56 at
title: Hamilton Held to 59 In Victory

body: Walter Berry, a senior center, scored 25 points, and Ken Hutchinson, a junior forward, had 17 to lead Benjamin Franklin to a 67-60 victory over DeWitt Clinton in opening-round play of the Public Schools Athletic League boys' tournament yesterday. The game, played at Brandeis High in Manhattan, marked the end of a long-standing interborough rivalry.
title: Franklin Tops Clinton; Berry Scores 25 Points

body: Alexander Hamilton, which had gained the final berth of the Public Schools Athletic League playoffs with a third-place finish in the Brooklyn III division, began its title defense yesterday with a 100-73 victory over Thomas Jefferson at South Shore High School. It was the ninth time this season that Hamilton had scored more than 100 points. Andre
title: Hamilton Scores 100 In Playoffs

body: On a June afternoon in 1913, when an army of schoolboys dressed in white shirts and dark knickerbockers demonstrated their physical skills at a Central Park extravaganza, Theodore Roosevelt clapped youngsters on the back with cries of ''Bully!'' and congratulated the Public Schools Athletic League for ''making these boys good young Americans.''
title: CITY'S PUBLIC SCHOOL ATHLETICS ERODED BY YEARS OF CUTBACKS

body: From his executive suite in the Greenpoint section of Brooklyn, Vic Barouh can check the sales reports from his $150 million officeequipment empire, call his factories in Ireland and Puerto Rico, watch his Ko-Rec-Type trucks fill on the loading docks and recall the day he started his business in 1955 with $48,000. What he finds himself thinking
title: AN ANGRY BUSINESSMAN'S WAR ON CRIME

body: Sol David, who survived Nazi concentration camps in World War II only to be murdered in Brooklyn by a robber who killed him with a single bullet, was buried yesterday. With Mr. David's widow, Flora, sobbing uncontrollably as relatives sought to comfort her, Rabbi Paul Gruber told more than 50 mourners at the Flatbush funeral service that ''we
title: A DEATH CAMP SURVIVOR, SLAIN BY MUGGERS, BURIED

body: International Israel has reassured the United States that it will not make attacks in Lebanon unless there is a ''clear provocation'' from Palestinian or Syrian forces, according to Israeli and Reagan Administration sources. The pledge was made, they said, by Prime Minister Begin in a letter to President Reagan. (Page A1, Column 1.) Washington
title: News Summary; THURSDAY, JANUARY 21, 1982

body: A 17-year-old youth was charged yesterday with shooting a woman in the head and stealing her purse, which contained only 50 c ents. The woman, who is 31 and has an 8-year-old son, was in critical conditionat Kings Coun ty Hospital. The youth was identified by the police as Kenrick Austin of 670 Remsen Avenue, Brooklyn. He was picked up shortly
title: WOMAN SHOT AND ROBBED OF 50¦

body: A woman was shot in the head on a street in the Canarsie section of Brooklyn yesterday evening by an armed robber who escaped with all the money she had on her - $10. The police identified the victim as Adian Barnes, 31 years old, of Brooklyn. Her condition was listed as critical at Kings County Hospital where she was taken after the shooting. Sgt.
title: THE CITY; Woman Is Shot On Canarsie Street
